description: From Latin expectāre, infinitive form of exspectō (“look out for, await, expect”), from ex (“out”) + spectō (“look at”), frequentative of speciō (“see”).

verbs.description: expect (third-person singular simple present expects, present participle expecting, simple past and past participle expected)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To predict or believe that something will happen
examples: I expect to be able to walk again after getting over my broken leg.
He never expected to be discovered.
We ended up waiting a little longer than we had expected
The doctor said he expected me to make a full recovery.
You are expected to get the task done by the end of next week.

entries.meaning: (continuous aspect only, of a woman or couple) To be pregnant, to consider a baby due.
examples: “You are pregnant?” he asked with shock in his voice. “Yes, Justin, I am expecting a child,”

entries.meaning: (obsolete, transitive) To wait for; to await.
examples: Synonyms: await; see also Thesaurus:wait for
